body: and also BlockingItemQueue Test.
The entrypoint for query is `ThriftQueryService` not `QueryService`

Good progress! Here are some thoughts:
- I wouldn't block this on embedded cassandra, as that's polish. We can just use travis service/local cassandra for now (like we do today).
- Mixed feelings about the separate `-java` and `-aggregate` projects. The artifact graph is already complex, and something we've been working hard to make sense of. Can we delay this optimization? For example, add a java source tree and make the deps for `-aggregate` optional. 

I can help look at the test, but any chance you can move this branch to openzipkin? Easier for us to collaborate there.
ps.. given a choice, I'd just delete cassandra-aggregate vs move it to an incompatible peer project. I'm sure @eirslett if not others could make short work of that once the core cassandra is in.

Based on offline chat, here's my take:
- the `-java` project is already in use for a project that writes traces directly into cassandra vs via scribe etc. Maybe the name could be changed, but understand where that's coming from. Personally, I prefer `-core` suffix for library code.
- we should definitely delete the -aggregate codebase as opposed to orphaning it in a way that doesn't compile. This is part of collateral damage needed to get zipkin running again. Hopefully, @eirslett could help add a new `-aggregate` codebase after this is merged (based on git history or from scratch).

Need some folks to weigh in, as I'd like to depend on this work in order to complete other work (like removing Index/Store, and the Builder stuff).

answering @adriancole's points
- the name of the pure-java impl
  - not sure if java needs to be in the name since its self evident?  +1 to core or something based on current name scheme.
- whether it is ok to ditch cassandra-aggregates temporarily
  - :+1: , but don't know if there's people out there that might be in an awkward spot, hopefully they come on gitter and ask for help.

the `-core` suffix is a nice choice over `-java`.  so +1 on that.

also +1 on removing `-aggregate`. just so long enough people know where it went if questions are raised later on by those that didn't catch it here.
Wow, this is some Great work! :grinning: :clap: :+1:
We can run zipkin-aggregate off a released version of zipkin-cassandra (with cassie). For now. But I'm pretty sure @michaelsembwever has some experience working with Cassandra taps?

Great point. Once our jars are published, we could switch the dep in the
aggregated module until the new code is ported over.
ok PTAL
Interesting that you uncovered the testing framework.  I restarted the travis job, but there was a problem with the redis span store spec.  Not sure if this is an intermittent failure or not.
yeah, well redis didn't actually run the tests prior (only did clear() actually!), so there may be some flakes to squash over time. beats zero coverage, though!
ok build's green. I will help with flakes or disabling things that flake on certain backends.

rebased off master and included commits from @adriancole 's branch in https://github.com/thelastpickle/zipkin/pull/1

zipkin-cassandra-aggregate is removed.
zipkin-cassandra-java is now called zipkin-cassandra-core.

CassieSpanStoreFactory renamed to CassandraSpanStoreFactory
CassieSpanStoreSpec renamed to CassandraSpanStoreSpec

from here i'll fix up the tests and incorporate @eirslet's improvements.
:shipit:
:clap:
deploys fine internally at twitter
:+1: looks good. So much red!
will merge on green. Thanks for having a look @abesto!
+cc @jamescway @adriancole
Is zipkin the most continuously delivered product at Twitter now? :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye:
must be in the runnings :)
makes sense
Closing as fixed, feel free to reopen / open another issue if things are still borken.
weird.. I thought `./gradlew install` already did this?
nice alternate workaround :smile:  :+1:
:+1:  cool new yield obj
@adriancole I entirely missed reading that task as  `./gradlew tasks`  placed `publishToMavenLocal` before the `install` task. We might just need to hide the `publishToMavenLocal` task
Sounds confusing for sure.
:+1: lgtm
verified instructions in README still work, as well.

Here are some hints on how to retain support for Builder w/o having to implement Index or Storage:

there's a bridge you can use ex here: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-collector-service/config/collector-redis.scala#L30
also here https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/583/files#diff-1b0789c140f012e2404ae48339a50569
added longer timeouts for all Awaits in ItemQueueTest, due to failures in travis
folks who might care to weigh in: @eirslett @jpinner @niteshkant @dsyer @spencergibb

I have no strong opinions. Scala traits (e.g. SpanStore) aren't instantiatable from Java anyways, you'll need to make an abstract class that mixes in the trait, and then in Java extend from that class. Will moving to j.u.Closeable solve that?
thanks!

It gets us closer, I think. It seems SpanStore could transition to an
interface if it wasn't being mixed in with traits itself.
+1 LGTM! :beers:

The following commit completes this change https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin/commit/84731aca6a4d162bce404580723be874beaef0d9

I'll raise a PR, squashing that into mck's work.
raised #585 to merge this in (removing the temp commits and squashing)

AFAICT, the only thing left is to make sure tests pass. If they don't, I'll update the PR so that they do!

cc @eirslett @michaelsembwever
at least locally, this deflakes the test https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin/commit/ab2b69f8c4ce53d2eef91b168afe5a5b49f33abf
updated with https://github.com/adriancole/zipkin/commit/7cf1880dc70f91f872fae11fa6776fe5ff622fe3 to honor cassandra dest

tested via the following:

``` bash
./gradlew :zipkin-aggregate:run
# and in separate windows
bin/collector cassandra
bin/query cassandra
bin/web
bin/tracegen
open http://localhost:8080/
```
going to merge on green eventhough #585 will obviate it. Almost done the cleanup, and this makes that work easier.

Sweet!
A last, finishing touch; should we add a migration guide or changelog? Where the TLDR version is; wipe your old Cassandra keyspace and start from scratch?

it's going to start from scratch anyway. any migration guide needs to
- inform that existing data will be "lost" (in a now unused keyspace),
- "zipkin.store.cassie" flags have changed to "zipkin.store.cassandra", and most of them removed,
- we only support Cassandra-2.0+ (i suspect we still support C*-1.2 but it'll be nice to not say that)
+1 :beers:

i did a force push here to incorporate some small additions (i forgot to keep those commits separate like @adriancole did above, my bad)
- add CassandraSpanStoreFactory.createClusterBuilder() and added into the default implementation retryPolicy and loadBalancingPolicy,
- removed lots of unused or unneeded options,
- renamed all remaining flags to use the "zipkin.store.cassandra." prefix
couldn't find any implementation that was not a no-op or throws an exception, not even at twitter.
+1 sweet! Real time aggregates is still only a sweet dream, I'm afraid...
thanks for the look, folks
ok looks like all left is docs. I'm doing a rebase to see if it can go green
i've done a round with bin/collector|query|web|tracegen  and am happy with runtime.
anything other than README.md and CHANGELOG you'd like me to update?
@michaelsembwever as far as I'm concerned :shipit:

can't actually see anything in README.md that's relevant.
just CHANGELOG, and there are we talking about changes for "1.2.1" ?
@michaelsembwever yeah it is more about when we actually release 1.2.whatever. There's more to it than just cassandra.
need a step here #579 iotw
ok rebased for clean merge. just awaiting travis

Ok, then i would have added to CHANGES the following 

```
# 1.2.1
* Cassandra
  * Replaced internally cloned Cassie with the DataStax CQL driver
  * Change keyspace name from "Zipkin" to "zipkin"
  * Automatic schema creation on first start
```

but i let you do that in master or in #579
@michaelsembwever added your note for release here. thx!

FYI I'm stripping off the span store spec into a separate PR. The spec is entirely reliable on my machine, but something travis related is crashing it. Rather than thrash this PR, I'll spin it out and work on it independently.
tested using `bin/collector`, `bin/query`, `bin/tracegen`, and `bin/web` on dev cassandra and redis

I think this should wait until we can build Java 8 bytecode. As @eirslett says.. there's a lot of other things that limit work, and Closeable is just part of it. interfaces with default methods are the bridge point, but unfortunately there's a lot in our dep chain that isn't java 8 ready.

Done have a ton of context, but everything lgtm except that one thing, which I'm assuming is necessary.
:+1:  nice deletes :100:

I think the `try-with-resources` is a good case for using `java.io.Closeable` which makes the code terse so +1 for that! In RxNetty, the primary usage of close is async, so, I couldn't use `Closeable`.
so does that put you in the "both" camp? :)

:) I think they both have their uses. I would use async `close()` for something like a channel, request, response, etc which will be called inline with request processing. For infrequent tasks, a synchronous close is appropriate/sufficient. I do not have insight into zipkin code to have an opinion about specific `close()` uses.
Build is green, didn't see anything bc-breaking affecting us in the release notes, so sure, :shipit:
Nice! I had forgotten about all this stuff in my haste on #585. Thanks.

SpanStore is the storage behind collectors or query services. In current implementations, it is application scoped, and close is invoked as a shutdown hook. I will switch the title to SpanStore uses Closeable :)
This was collateral damage from moving off cassie. You can build aggregates from commit 6c68d55e0d1b62893d49dba81aa4224fba68ddcf for now.
I suspect the gradle daemon is getting killed on too much memory. Going to switch off gradle daemon on this PR to see if this is memory related or not.

@eirslett PTAL

cc @jpinner @NiteshKant
updated with the trivial change needed to make the other storage interface, Aggregates, java friendlier.

Here's the commit to resurrect files from: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/commit/6e8fdad0bfa4c1de16215841f4c04f9710e3e686#diff-9e4ef735c2cc6a6622c3f51167c24b80

Note: when re-implementing this. I think it is preferable to put the hadoop/scalding code for cassandra into the `zipkin-aggregate` tree rather than `zipkin-cassandra`. `zipkin-aggregate` is the only user of this, and it is relatively dependency heavy.
this passes when not using the gradle daemon. I suspect this is memory related, as watching the test run in jconsole, my JVM spiked to 3.5GB memory.
@michaelsembwever I may be off in my assessment, but anyway, this "greens", but only if we disable the gradle daemon (which slows the build by 5m)
these sound like miles forward. thanks!

Yeah funny -b didn't fail before.
:+1:  looks like the red build is from publishing not building.

Thanks for checking! Just pushed another change to handle the last edge-cases I can think of, I think the builds should be green this time (won't even try to publish from building a branch / PR). If that happens, I'll go ahead and merge.

- Don't see the new travis.yml behavior?
- also I think the branch name set was not master (it was the tag name).  So in order to push the release notification commits to master, had to change the branch.

Wrt/ new travis.yml behaviour: yeah, don't know what's up with that. Hope it'll go away if this goes into master, will do some research in the meanwhile.

Wrt/ checkout: yep, I've moved the git checkout to just before the call to `./gradlew release` to minimize side-effects and keep the "main" logic clean. AFAICT nothing else should need it; does that sound right?
Re: `./gradlew assemble`: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/26566564/override-default-travis-ci-script-for-java-gradle-project :)
:shipit:
I'm ok with this. :shipit:
CC @jamescway @adriancole @rtyler
thanks, @abesto.. let's give this a shot!
